info.game_comments:
Hunter Appler game 3.
WE ASKED: Artist Lin-Manuel Miranda.

(2, 1).clue: This place where alcoholic drinks are sold is derived from a slightly shorter, "fashionable" French word

(3, 1).clue: Yes, that's a roller coaster passing through the centerless Big O Ferris wheel in this capital of Japan

(4, 1).clue: (I'm Lin-Manuel Miranda.)  In 2008 I won a Tony for Best Original Score for my musical "In the Heights"; that is, Washington Heights, far uptown in this borough

(5, 1).clue: 1650:The 787-carat Great Mogul Diamond is found in a mine in this country

(2, 2).clue: From Latin for "cleanse", it's the place where one's soul is cleansed before entering heaven

(4, 2).clue: 2012's Best Original Screenplay Oscar went to him for "Django Unchained"

(5, 2).clue: 1350:In the great battle of Les Espagnols sur Mer, an English fleet defeats one from this nation

(6, 2).clue: Andrew W. Mellon,Henry M. Paulson,George P. Shultz

(2, 3).clue: Often eaten with eggs at breakfast, it comes from Latin for "dry" or "parch"

(4, 3).clue: In 1962 Don Drysdale won the Cy Young Award; the next year it was this Dodgers teammate

(5, 3).clue: 1850:Henry Clay, the "Great" this-"er", gets Congress to adopt this

(1, 4).clue: This ancient Basque sport uses a weaved basketlike glove called a cesta & a ball called a pelota

(2, 4).clue: From a word for "apple", it's a bag of aromatic substances placed in a dresser drawer

(3, 4).clue: Koromo got this new name in 1959 to reflect the importance of its major employer, an auto manufacturer

(4, 4).clue: From 2000 through 2003 this fast-moving, fast-talking political drama won the Drama Series Emmy

(5, 4).clue: 1950:In Boston "Fats" Pino & 10 accomplices pull off the "Great" this company "Robbery"

(1, 5).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew presents.)  In basket weaving, the weft is a moving horizontal fiber; & this other 4-letter word refers to a vertical stationary fiber

(2, 5).clue: In Dutch it meant "household effects"; its meaning as goods taken by force during a war dates to the 1640s

(3, 5).clue: This city was home to the royal family for 1,074 years, from the Heian Period to the Meiji Restoration

(4, 5).clue: This stammering comedian with "new" in his name won the 1960 Best New Artist Grammy

(5, 5).clue: 1250:The death of Frederick II ushers in the "Great" this, from the Latin for "between" & "reign"

(1, 1).clue: Dude!  He played Jack Baker, one half of "The Fabulous" piano-playing "Baker Boys"

(2, 1).clue: Salt Lake City structure where you'll find an 11,000-pipe organ

(3, 1).clue: Caprino, usually made from the milk of this animal, is a soft cheese that will highlight your spinach omelet

(4, 1).clue: Chess piece that fits the category

(5, 1).clue: "Though I've belted you an' flayed you, by the livin' Gawd that made you, you're a better man than I am", this character

(6, 1).clue: In the late 1800s this "fly away home" beetle was brought in to save California's citrus crops from insect pests

(1, 2).clue: Goodness, gracious, Dennis Quaid pounded the ivories in this 1989 biopic; catch Alec Baldwin as Jimmy Swaggart

(2, 2).clue: The chimeras have a great view of Paris from this cathedral that they decorate

(3, 2).clue: This Italian ice cream is denser than regular ice cream & has less butterfat

(4, 2).clue: Time to give us this time of day

(5, 2).clue: This musician character claimed to have a secret charm that he chiefly used "on creatures that do people harm"

(6, 2).clue: This type of beetle with a biblical name is one of the largest, growing about 5 inches long & weighing 3 1/2 oz.

(1, 3).clue: Adrien Brody's performance as "The Pianist" helped this controversial director win an Oscar

(2, 3).clue: This small shrine, the cube-shaped structure towards which Muslims orient themselves & pray, is in the Great Mosque

(3, 3).clue: This tiny rice-shaped pasta whose name means "barley" is often used in soups

(4, 3).clue: To secure a ship by cables

(5, 3).clue: "In silver armour", this Tennyson knight "saw the grail, the Holy Grail, descend upon the shrine"

(6, 3).clue: Consisting of 3 segments, each with a pair of legs, this forms the middle of a beetle's body

(1, 4).clue: As the mute Ada McGrath, this actress went to New Zealand with "The Piano" in 1993

(2, 4).clue: On a trip to Yangon in this country, visit the Shwedagon Pagoda, said to enshrine strands of Buddha's hair

(3, 4).clue: Spaghetti alle vongole is spaghetti served with these shellfish

(4, 4).clue: If you're "in" this furrow, you're doing very well

(6, 4).clue: The male of the American this beetle is a dark brown scarab, about 1 inch long, with a single upright horn

(1, 5).clue: He played Bobby Dupea, a classical pianist turned oil rigger, a man who ordered a chicken salad sandwich, hold the chicken

(2, 5).clue: Sri Harmandir Sahib, or the Golden Temple, in the Punjab city of Amritsar, is a holy site in this religion

(3, 5).clue: This bread salad is made with bread soaked in water, onions, tomatoes, basil, olive oil, vinegar & seasonings

(4, 5).clue: Profession of J.P.F. Blanchard, the first man to see Philadelphia from the air

(5, 5).clue: A.E. Housman hadn't visited Shropshire when he used it in the title of this 1896 collection

(6, 5).clue: Totaling about 8,000 species, this beetle gets its name from the sound it makes when it jumps

(0, 0).clue: Of his greatest accomplishment, he humbly remarked, "Pilots... take pride in a good landing, not in getting out of the vehicle"
